metadata.title: Lisfranc Joint Injury
anatomical location body part affected: Foot/Lisfranc ligament; tarsometatarsal joint complex; transverse arch
description: The Lisfranc ligament is the primary stabilizer of the tarsometatarsal joint complex. It spans the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal(9)

“Lisfranc injury” is a general term for tarsometatarsal injuries that involve the Lisfranc ligament complex and range from an undisplaced mild sprain to severe fracture and dislocation. The severity of displacement is often underestimated on the initial clinical exam soon after injury

General classification of Lisfranc sprains and injuries(1) –Grade 1: Tenderness at the joint complex, but minimal swelling and no instability –Grade 2: Tenderness and swelling, mild laxity but no instability –Grade 3: Complete osteo-ligamentous  disruption, possibly including fracture dislocation, with 2 mm or more joint diastasis
Displacement (often dorsally) of the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bases greater than 2 mm on x-ray  indicates ligamentous instability and the need for surgical fixation to reduce the dislocation
Restoration and maintenance of the anatomic alignment of the Lisfranc joint is the key to appropriate management(9)
A severe Lisfranc dislocation has a high potential for chronic disability, even with surgical correction, and for athletes can be a season-  or career-ending  injury

Mobility G-code set.G8978: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Mobility G-code set.G8979: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation; projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Mobility G-code set.G8980: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients with a nondisplaced sprain may present for therapy able to bear weight, possibly after wearing a short leg cast or walking boot

In subacute cases –Unilateral pain primarily in the dorsal midfoot area; aggravated by weight-bearing  (WB) through forefoot –Localized tenderness along the tarsometatarsal articulations –Swelling/edema over the dorsal midfoot –Bruising/ecchymosis in the midfoot and often including the forefoot –Hematoma after trauma –Restricted WB on foot

In chronic cases –Foot muscle weakness related to pain –Stiffness and reduced forefoot range of motion (ROM) –Limited WB –Antalgic gait: pain and instability are worse during the push-off  phase (especially walking uphill) –Disturbed standing balance due to pain
Patients with crush injuries may present with repaired soft tissue Causes, Pathogenesis, and Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the examination and notify physician immediately for possible referral to emergency room if the patient reports no sensation in the affected foot or cannot demonstrate a requested motor response
Consider postponing the exam in cases with unresolved inflammation, infection/healing of soft tissue, or severe hematoma

causes ,,: Direct high-energy  trauma or impact force (such as in motor vehicle accident, fall from height, or crush injury); associatedwith fracture/dislocation
Indirect injury resulting from sudden, forced axial (longitudinal) torque on the Lisfranc joint complex
pathogenesis ,,: 1st and 2nd metatarsal-cuneiform  joints are most often dislocated
Fleck sign: avulsion of Lisfranc ligament at 2nd metatarsal base

Improper alignment of the tarsometatarsal joints may cause erosion of the dorsal and lateral aspects of the cuneiforms andresult in valgus abduction deformity of forefoot–A possible cause of chronic metatarsalgia–Increases risk of osteoarthritis
risk factors ,,: Factors that may weaken the foot bones or longitudinal arch–Obesity (i.e., increased foot stress on WB)–Osteoporosis–Diabetes
Foot straps used in some sports
Extreme plantar flexion during pointe position and time spent in pointe position in dancers(11)

overall contraindications precautions: Pain associated with obvious physical deformity of the foot
Inability to bear weight on foot due to severe pain
Severe swelling of foot in a patient with apparent febrile illness
Stop the examination or treatment and notify physician immediately if the patient has neurovascular signs and symptoms that indicate lower leg compartment syndrome (often a medical emergency)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Stop the examination and notify physician immediately for possible referral to emergency room if the patient reports no sensation in the affected foot or cannot demonstrate a requested motor response
Consider postponing the exam in cases with unresolved inflammation, infection/healing of soft tissue, or severe hematoma

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Ask about any specific trauma, strain, or overuse (see  Causes , above). How have symptoms progressed since onset? Is WB limited or restricted?

course of treatment.medical management: Care will vary depending on the severity of injury. Did the patient receive any emergency care?immobilization/bracing, activity modification, WB precautions, etc.)?
surgical management: Surgical management:  Was any surgical intervention performed? Different fixation options are used with open reduction to treat Lisfranc injuries. If so, what was date of surgery and what method was used? How well has the incision healed (any infection)? Was the foot immobilized in a plaster cast (for how long?) or was a cam walker used? Unstable Lisfranc injuries typically require surgical management(12)
Suture button fixation, or “flexible fixation”, is a surgical option for elite athletes/dancers who cannot tolerate a rigid screw fixation(14)
Current standard of surgical care for non-dancers  is ORIF or fusion
Arthrodesis is recommended for ligamentous injuries involving the medial and middle columns or comminuted
Return to sport after surgery may take six months to a year(15)
course of treatment.medications: Medications commonly used to treat acute foot pain include acetaminophen, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory  drugs (NSAIDs), and opioid derivatives such as hydrocodone
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Ask about plain radiographs, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and bone scintigraphy.
Weightbearing  plain radiographs are recommended(12) CT scans may be used when plain radiographs are unable to identify subtleties(13)
Lateral radiographs may show a step-off sign(13)
In a normal foot there should not be more than 2 mm between the first and second metatarsal, increased distance suggest Lisfranc injury(13)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for other lower extremity injuries/conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Pain of a fracture or stress fracture or displaced joint worsens with WB and increases further with ambulation -Is relief obtained by wearing shoes or taping?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Burning pain and numbness are characteristic of nerve entrapment such as in tarsal tunnel syndrome -Does the pain increase with pressure? To what extent is WB tolerated? -Any paresthesia/weakness suggestive of peripheral nerve injury?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess pain
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if applicable
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., lower extremity weakness, dizziness, lumbosacral radicular pain, falls)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in competitive sports? What does the patient’s occupation involve? What do his or her daily activities involve?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: If applicable, assess the current ambulatory assistive device for proper fit and use, or evaluate for suitable ambulatory assistive device, as indicated. Determine the need for supportive/protective equipment, footwear, or orthotics
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess standing static and dynamic balance on both feet and, when appropriate, in single-leg  stand and also on toes and heels
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess for palpable foot pulses, i.e., dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis arteries. The perforating branch of dorsalis pedis courses between the bases of the 1st and 2nd metatarsals and may be damagedAssess foot edema with girth measurements; compare to unaffected foot
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess WB status, ability in transfers (e.g., chair to stand), stair climbing, and walking ability. American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) midfoot scores correlated well with V AS scores in 26 patients with isolated Lisfranc fracture dislocation(4)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: If patient is ambulatory, observe for altered/antalgic gait pattern in walking (and running, when appropriate, in athletes). Assess lower extremity/rearfoot alignment and movement of foot in barefooted walking, and width of stance. Reduced forefoot contact time was found at median follow-up  of 76 months after Lisfranc injury(4)Assess forefoot flexibility as tolerated the heel in neutral position. Pain at the base of the 1st and 2nd metatarsals is consistent with Lisfranc injury. Assess for gross instability and crepitus
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength as tolerated in ankle plantar flexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, eversion; forefoot adduction/abduction; toe flexion/extension
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect skin for cellulitis or wound infection, if applicable

Palpate foot and document tenderness. Acute swelling may limit palpation. Expect tenderness at the navicular, medial cuneiform, base of the 1st and 5th metatarsal, and the 1st and 2nd metatarsal interspace
Assess subtalar neutral in non-WB •Pain:  Assess with V AS (at best, at worst, and at the moment)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess foot and leg alignment in non-WB  and, if tolerated and allowed, in standing bearing weight
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM of foot in plantar flexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, eversion, supination, and pronation. Passive pronation and abduction or dorsiflexion and abduction of the forefoot may elicit pain and/or apprehension. Assess ROM of hallux. Compare bilaterally
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess for sensory deficits in affected foot with nylon monofilament test, if indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –AOFAS midfoot score(4) –Piano Key Test(15) -Metatarsal is grasped and moved into dorsiflexion and plantarflexion. A positive test elicits pain

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Subacute or chronic Lisfranc injury/foot pain, swelling, tenderness, stiffness, weakness, reduced tolerance for WB, disability in daily activities Lisfranc joint injuries require a high degree of suspicion in order to make a prompt accurate diagnosis, due to their subtle exam and radiographic presentation. Missed or delayed diagnoses occur in 20-35%  of cases(11)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Cuboid fracture, medial cuneiform fracture, avulsion fracture of the navicular tuberosity, metatarsalgia, Morton’s neuroma, lower leg compartment syndrome, complex regional pain syndrome
prognosis: In minor and moderate sprains (grades 1 and 2), resolution of pain on standing and recovery of ambulatory function should occur within 6 weeks(3)

Some Lisfranc injuries treated by closed-reduction  (under fluoroscopy) and internal fixation (CRIF) may have a poor outcome. For example, a case of interposition of the tibialis anterior tendon required revision by open reduction(6)
Severe soft tissue injury and incomplete reduction after surgery are negative prognostic factors in Lisfranc injuries, based on a retrospective follow-up  study (N = 32; 55 months) in Turkey(10)
Missed or delayed diagnoses may lead to poor long-term  outcome including premature retirement form athletic activities due to disabling pain, ligamentous instability, and degenerative arthritis(10)
Return to sport after surgical treatment is expected to take at least 6 months(15)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthotist/pedorthist for shoe modifications, orthoses, and orthopedic footwear. An orthotic with a supportive arch is recommended for the first few months after return to athletic activities(3,7) Physician for medical consult regarding pain management Orthopedist for surgical consult for evaluation and possible realignment arthrodesis in cases with chronic (> 6 weeks) pain Acupuncturist for alternative pain management
other considerations: Progressive WB can begin about 3 months after surgery(7)
Educate athletes that the Lisfranc fracture often requires a long course of recovery and that return to their former level of play may take longer than anticipated(8)
treatment summary: Acute and subacute phases: Substitute upper body exercise (e.g., arm cycling, swimming, weight lifting) to maintain fitness during foot healing period

A grade 1 or 2 sprain is usually treated conservatively with a non-WB cast and/or walking cast for 4-6 wks(3) –A nondisplaced Lisfranc fracture without ligament instability is usually casted for 6 weeks, followed by cam walker for 6 weeks, and no running/jumping for 3 months(3) –Surgical reduction is recommended for ligamentous disruption with joint displacement greater than 2 mm, followed by 3 to 4 months of immobilization in a removable cast(6)

Functional rehabilitation phase –Exercises to improve foot ROM, strength, and function after surgical reduction(6) -ROM exercises can begin at 6-8 weeks -Progressive WB can begin at 3 months . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Foot pain; tender and swollen tissuesResolve pain and inflammation of soft tissuesPhysical agents and electrotherapeutic modalities _ Implement cryotherapeutic agents and the PRICE approach for pain and edema management. Studies are lacking on the effectiveness of electrotherapeutic modalities for treating Lisfranc injuriesAllow at least 6 weeks for fracture healing and 6 additional weeks for complete resolution of tenderness and swellingProvide patient with instructions for the PRICE approach to control pain and swelling  Reduced foot ROM, flexibility, strength and enduranceRestore or improve physical fitness for return to full activitiesTherapeutic modalities _ ROM and strengthening exercises as indicated. Modes of aerobic training that match patient’s ability (e.g., arm cycling, aquatics, elliptical trainer, treadmill walking) _ _ Lower extremity resistance training can begin after regaining painless AROM. Manual and assisted stretching exercises to regain full PROMGradually progress intensity of exercises before full WB; therapeutic exercises 3x per week for 4 weeks. The intensity and duration of exercises should be progressed in the final phase to restore fitness for work and sportProvide the patient with simple strengthening. Daily repetition of exercises Abnormal standing posture, nonsymmetrical or antalgic WB and gait; increased risk of fallsRestoration of symmetry in standing posture and WB activities; normal gait mechanicsFunctional training _ Posture and gait reeducationProgress WB as tolerated. Gradual progression of exercises to allow additional WB. Increase speed and complexity of movementsProvide patient and family/ caregivers with written instructions regarding functional activities that can be performed at home Functional decline in performance of affected leg: reduced balance, walking ability, stair climbing; with increased risk of fallsImprove functional balance and walking endurance, with independence in fall prevention strategiesFunctional training (5) _ Sitting balance ball exercises for partial WB, standing balance exercises, full WB activities _ _ Implement proprioception training tools as indicated and when appropriate: pillow, foam pad, BAPS, wobble diskProgress weight- bearing as tolerated. Gradual progression of exercises to allow additional WB. Increase speed and complexity of movementsProvide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding functional activities that can be performed at home  Non- or partial WB. Use of ambulatory assistive device. Improper athletic footwearProtect healing tissues Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Assistive devices and orthotics, as indicated. Taping and shoe modifications may help support/protect affected tissues. Custom in- shoe foot orthoses are recommended for athletes(3)Wean from ambulatory assistive devices as appropriateCorrect use of assistive devices and/or application of equipment. Compliance with recommended foot wear .

return to prior regular physical activit: Short Form Health-Related  Quality of Life Questionnaire (SF-36)

maintenance or prevention: Maintenance of specific flexibility and agility for sport
Use of protective equipment and proper footwear
patient education: See American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Web site, https://www.foothealthfacts.org/conditions/lisfranc-injuries Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
